Based on the OCT, what is the most likely preliminary diagnosis?

answers.answerText: A. Myelin Oligodendrocyte Glycoprotein Associated Optic Neuriti

answers.explanation:
As we age, the vitreous liquefies and contracts, exerting tractional forces on the retina and optic nerve head. The vitreous is most adherent at the optic nerve, and thus vitreopapillary traction is a phenomenon where the posterior hyaloid remains adherent to the optic nerve head, elevating it to produce a swollen disc appearance.1 OCT imaging allows for visualisation of the vitreopapillary interface as a hyper-reflective band adherent to the optic nerve (yellow arrows)

![](/content/media/neuro5.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: If this patient was asymptomatic and had no previous medical/ocular history, what further testing would be required?

answers.explanation: It is important to keep vitreopapillary traction on the differential of patients with asymptomatic unilateral optic disc edema. As OCT imaging is non-invasive and non-ionizing, confirmation of vitreopapillary traction may save patients from unnecessary testing. However, some patients have reported blurriness, visual field defects, and/or gaze evoked amaurosis.2 In symptomatic patients, clinical correlation is required to decide on appropriate investigation course, as presence of vitreopapillary traction does not rule out the concurrence of a second underlying disorder.

title: Case 33
description: 67M referred for suspected optic neuropathy OS
patientPresentation:
A 67-year-old man was referred to a tertiary neuro-ophthalmology clinic for suspected left optic neuropathy. He reported a 3-month history of blurred and distorted vision in his left eye, and a central scotoma that fluctuated when laying flat/bending forward. He denied pain, redness/photophobia, flashes/floaters, or peripheral field defects. Ocular history was significant for non-granulomatous anterior uveitis (work-up negative) and cystoid macular edema with an associated previous episode of optic nerve head edema, which was treated with topical corticosteroid drops 5 years prior.
